job_title: HPS I in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Great historic places to work and great local staff and management.
cons: Shambolic Senior management. Poor wages

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Good work life balance between office and home
cons: Poor direction from the senior management

job_title: Assistant Gardener in Eltham, England
pros: Beautiful locations Nice plants Public can be friendly
cons: So many. A bullying, gaslighting, nasty place to work. Senior management are egotistical narcissists and lazy. Expect you to do your job to the point of exhaustion. Any problems flagged up then that person is ostracised. Really bad… if you’re ill you are literally badgered until you leave. You can’t speak whilst working. Senior management and above treat lower positions with distain or encourage tattle telling. Toxic place to work. Rely heavily on bolunteers. No respect to staff

review_title: Mostly good experience but management pitfalls
job_title: Visitor Assistant in Whitby, England
pros: Nice staff with a good community, management is good at choosing employees and typically chooses staff members that have interesting and dynamic personalities so most people are fun to work with. Employs a wide range of individuals in terms of age and background. Nice historic place to work.
cons: Often understaffed during the busy seasons. Difficult to access the site on foot as it's up a steep hill so always a workout every morning (could be a pro if you have the time to make the journey and don't mind coming to work sweating before the day has started). Requested a full-time contract but was never fulfilled. Very sales heavy despite appearing to be a customer service role, with lots of emphasis on the number of memberships sold per day as that was the main priority for management.

job_title: Visitor Assistant in East Cowes, England
pros: Benefits and great working group
cons: The management is a disaster. Lack of communication and organization.

job_title: Barista in Downe, England
pros: Lots of training and help, lovely people.
cons: Not any in my experience

job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros: A few lovely individuals with a lot of potential!
cons:
Unfortunately, some of these previous comments here are not untrue: 

- A lot (understatement) of miscommunication from all boards.
Some team members' comments are distorted and taken out of context then reported incorrectly to senior management to intentionally cause harm to individuals involved

- Some team leaders lead the way to gossips, also create and feed team conflicts whilst pretending to solve the said conflicts. There is therefore an element of mistrust. 

- Chances are you will work with an insecure narcissist who gets angry within seconds for unwarranted reasons, and feels entitled to bully and belittle their line manager in front of the team as well as in front of the senior manager, who allows such behaviours because "they cannot afford to lose this leader"

- You shall expect some colleagues to spy on you and make you feel unwelcome.
Not only will they watch what/how much you eat or drink and make unpleasant comments to you about it, but they then will also relay their findings to senior management

- Ensure you have been paid correctly, with all your holidays included.

- It really is saddening that some team members complain about the fact that the senior managers do not care at all about them and very rarely engage with them. This results in the team members showing unwillingness to follow the management's directives, whom eventually loses credibility and influence on their team

job_title: Membership Supervisor in Birmingham, England

job_title: Visitor Assistant in Dartmouth, England

job_title: Supervisor in Craven Arms, England

review_title: Too many managers not enough workers
job_title: Anonymous Employee in York, England

cons: So many working groups and layers of managers but not enough people actually working and effecting positive change. Most of the actual work is done by a tiny handful of people. - Never any acknowledgment for a job well done.

job_title: Visitor Assistant in Leeds, England

The job is generally enjoyable and colleagues are lovely but the management don’t make staff feel valued in any way. Just attempting to pop round and have a casual chat once in a while would be nice!
cons: Being expected to work additional days and bank holidays with no recompense

job_title: Visitors Assistant in London, England

job_title: Catering Assistant in Framlingham, England

job_title: Customer Service in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England

job_title: Actor/Performer in Warwick, West Midlands, England

job_title: Historic Property Steward in London, England
pros:
- Working with historic places and art
- Meeting fantastic visitors
cons:
I am at a loss for words after many years here. Because of the low pay, English Heritage tends to attract lower-skilled and incompetency-prone individuals looking for an easy ride. Of course, there are some exceptions, but they usually progress to better things with time. 
HR is highly biased, and always talks about fairness but never demonstrates it. If there is a conflict between a male and a female, the HR will always take the female's side, regardless of the facts. And will always take the side of senior management not supporting the HPS’s, as demonstrated in numerous times.
The company has recently removed all employee benefits, such as night allowance, extra pay on bank holidays, and much more. With a few exceptions, senior management in the London area is generally unskilled. 
Lazy collection presentations or a complete lack of them, implying that the curatorial team is simply riding a wave of laziness and holding the job until it's time to retire. 
The most vexing aspect is the new diversity thing, in which EH literally uses staff members as tokens to claim they are secretly woke. There is no need because, the organisation is quite diverse and well represents its local audience.
Be ready to play office politics in a company where ineffectiveness reigns.

review_title: Great career opportunity for starting out.
job_title: National Sales Manager in London, England
pros: New manager was brilliant and very supportive.
cons: It takes an age to get anything approved or agreed to within the organisation. There is far too much politics.

job_title: Site Manager in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: Working outside, meeting interesting visitors

job_title: Assistant Events Manager in London, England

job_title: Customer Service Associate in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Supportive, kind, good opportunities, rewarding

job_title: SQL Developer in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England

review_title: Current staff paid less than new hires

Just look at the profiles of senior management on Linkedin. Criticism or querying of decision making is met with confrontation and aggression. Highly toxic.

job_title: Steward in York, England

review_title: Great training and mutual respect working for a great cause.
job_title: Archive Support Officer in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: Interesting environment.  Learning new skills.  Great support from line manager.  Criticism put in a constructive way.  Great appraisal scheme.  Team working and team building.  Interesting trips to other English Heritage sites.  Money off visits to English Heritage properties.  Some opportunities to be flexible in working hours.  Varied work so do not get bored.  Great lectures and company information to add to role.  Good support from Human Resources with any problems.  Opportunities to take part in training to further you in role.
cons: Working for a charity so not one of the highest paid jobs working for love of job and belief in cause.  Short term or temporary contracts may not be possible to find another appropriate job in the company after leaving. Need to have a sense of humour.  Need to be prepared to do physical work as well as a desk job.  Some jobs may be quite specialised so may not suit everyone.  Because it involves working for a charity have to be prepared to be resourceful in not wasting money or materials.  Need to be careful handling precious materials.

job_title: Head of IT in Woodford, London, England
pros: Great people and great organisation
cons: None I can think of

job_title: Site Manager in Barnard Castle, England
pros: The special people and the special places make English Heritage a great organisation to work for.  We get to meet many interesting visitors with stories to share, and can also take part in a variety of experiences within the company if so desired.  EH are very pro training, and one can avail ones self of a variety of courses to enhance personal development.
cons: Yes the hours can be long, and yes, you need to be positive, creative, but you get out of this job, precisely what you put in.  If you are clock watcher, and your glass is half empty, then don't bother applying - this isn't for you.  Alternatively, if you embrace life, enjoy chatting to folks that genuinely enjoy a great day out, and you feel you can add value to the customer experience, then English Heritage may just be the right organisation for you.

job_title: Steward in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros: There is absolutely nothing positive to say about working for English Heritage
cons:
The basic description of the job is that are actively expected to ruin visitors day by constantly pressuring them into spending more and more money. You do this for a pathetically low wage, working awful hours with zero job security.

If you have even the slightest ambition to work in anything other than a minimum wage customer service job you need to avoid working for English Heritage at all costs. They will actively go out of their way to trap you in a dead end job with absolutely no chances of career progression. Opportunities for additional training and progression will constantly be promised and never provided. The only training you will ever receive is the patronising mandatory retraining all front line staff have to every 12 months reminding you how to do a job you have been trapped in for years.

If/when you finally have enough and decide to leave, then your time at English Heritage will be of absolutely zero value to you in the jobs market. Years of working in such a monotonous job will leave you with almost not valuable skills and it is company policy to not provide high quality references for departing/former employees.

review_title: Building for the future - great to be a part of it...
job_title: Anonymous in York, England
pros: This is an organisation is transition.  There is a legacy of the past structure and this brings constraints but the appetite and ambition is very forward thinking.  Its great to be a part of this future and have the opportunity to bring my skills to the party.  Everybody is friendly and supportive - doing their job for the right reasons and care deeply about the work that EH does.  Fantastic locations, with privileged behind the scenes access focussed on building a sustainable future for the nation to enjoy.  I am proud to be a part of the journey.
cons: Wanting to deliver the best experience for our visitors but with the limitations of a charity budget can be challenging but it means that we have to be more creative in our thinking an approach.

review_title: If you want to progress in heritage don't apply here...
job_title: Historic Property Steward in York, England
pros: Loved working in some beautiful historic places as a historic properties steward and worked with some great site staff over the 4 and a half years employed there.
cons:
My site was freezing in winter with no provisions for keeping staff warm. 
The pay is abysmal. 
There were hardly any chances of progressing within the company. 
Limited training opportunities. 
I've also recently found out that my area manager had a vendetta against me and blocked any form of promotion within the company. She also added that to keep me quiet I was always to be given an interview for an internal job but not be given it. This is EXTREMELY unprofessional and I then wasted 18 months working there when I could have found a new job or career path. Because of this experience I will never apply for a job with English Heritage again.

job_title: Historic Properties Team Member in Salisbury, England
pros: A chance to work in some fabulous properties with interested and passionate people. Fine for a summer job but not for a career unless you are a brown nosed suit.
cons: The management has historically been poor and has known it. It has only recruited poorer management because it is afraid of competency. This fear means it is unable to make decisions without endless cycles of consultation and creates a feeling of impotency. Combining fear and impotency means they turn to bullying of the ranks and a retreat to simple number crunching of revenues. They completely waste the enormous talent and resource of the site staff and attack any sign of intelligence. They may talk the talk of employee relations but dismally fail.

review_title: Profit over visitor and staff experience
job_title: Historic Property Steward in York, England
pros: The opportunity to work in some of the most fantastic buildings in the country with free access to many more.
cons: After working in some fairly soulless corporate environments, I had expected that the charitable status of English Heritage would mean that the staff would be committed to the cause, this was not the case. Money came first for everything, over visitors, over staff, over the truth. I was frequently part of meetings where  teams were told to "treat sales like a dog with a bone" and "never take no for an answer", individuals' performances were highlighted in red in the break room to 'name and shame' those who were not hitting their targets. I have never worked in an organisation with such a high turnover of staff and low morale.

job_title: Historic Property Steward in Saltburn-by-the-Sea, England
pros:
Excellent team of people, all who want to work in some of the country's most important and iconic places.
Good work-life balance in my role as being only a steward  I don't take any work home with me. 
Perks, a very good staff discount. Vouchers from love to shop when the site reaches sales targets and retail targets.  Free entry to English Heritage properties. Festival of History is excellent.
cons:
seasonal work
potentially a lack of career opportunities moving up the ladder

review_title: Excellent employers with a proactive training programme for staff, and opportunities to relocate around the country.
job_title: Historic Properties Steward in Manchester, England
pros: Good standard of pay, paid high quality training courses, fantastic locations to work, flexible working conditions, good mixes of people working at all the sites. Good opportunities to work at other sites for events, ie Festival of History at Kelmarsh Hall.
cons:
If working at one of the sites, then most of the jobs are seasonal, which means you have to find something else in winter.

Occassional lack of communication from upper management.

job_title: Historic Property Steward in Gloucester, England
pros: Working with English Heritage has great benefits (free access to all EH sites, 20% discount in retail), and a lovely working atmosphere. It's a fun place to work if you enjoy history, and like chatting with tourists and promoting/selling memberships.
cons: Unfortunately, there are very few opportunities for staff to progress to supervisory or management roles, which - depending on the things your site offers - can mean very little career development. There is a lot of red tape and micro-management from upper management, with a 'one size fits all' theory which doesn't fit anyone.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros: Team is made up of fantastic people, they make it doable. Sites are often very beautiful. Free entry to other sites.
cons: Problematic rotas. Part time staff are treated as full time staff without consideration to their availability. Staff have little to no say in their hours. Asked to work night shifts which was not stated in interviews. Staff are often overworked, leading to sickness and more problems. Little to no training.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros:
- I made some great friends
- Interesting sites
cons:
- Toxic 'management is always right' culture
- Heavy handed and unconstructive management approach
- No progression by talent, you'll only progress if your manager leaves

This was probably the most toxic moment of my career. The work is slow, they do not take well to any kind of constructive improvement and management take all of the perks, all of the glory, and suck all of the joy out of the place. Avoid if you are even vaguely interesting, happy or ambitious.

job_title: Customer Service Adviser in Swindon, Wiltshire, South West England, England
pros: English Heritage was filled with the most lovely people and everyone was so supportive and friendly. They really made you feel welcome.
cons: Working in the contact centre the fact that their system and website wasn't the most intuitive or up-to-date was very clear. There were many things we take for granted that the system couldn't do and callers would ask "why?" usually quite angrily!

job_title: Catering Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
- The company is considerate towards part-time staff with additional commitments and respectful of how many hours I can work. 
- Surrounded by friendly colleagues who care about the organisation. 
- Pleasant working environment and the chance to share the story of each site with visitors.
cons:
- Limited communication with management (especially those based off-site) - many seem uninterested in 'lowly' catering assistants.
- Often understaffed

job_title: Ranger in East Cowes, England
pros: Great place to work - great staff. Comprehensive induction process.
cons: As the season gets busier management put profit and image  before staff forgetting that staff are their single most valuable asset in this industry. In five months immediate colleagues and I have never had breaks and are often on our feet for eight hours at a time and toilets  are inaccessible due to public demand. This is not acceptable but management show no desire to change.

job_title: in London, England
pros: A great place to work. Lots of interesting places to see. More than just a job!
cons: Lots to do and see. Can be exhausting after a while. A great place to work nonetheless.

job_title: Site Manager in Birmingham, England
pros: Working on site surrounded in history, generally lovely visitors, 25% retail staff discount & free entry to sites for you & your family
cons: Long hours through summer months, no time for breaks on small sites, lots of work at home to keep up to date with emails, poor pay.

job_title: Visitor Operations Team Member in York, England
pros: Great work places. Ruined castles, Abby's, stately homes etc. Free entry to other sites across the country. Working with others with the same interests. Training when available.
cons: High sales pressure from off site management. Senior management look down on lower pay grade staff, regardless of previous experience. Poor staff facilities.

job_title: Hospitality in Birmingham, England
pros: Amazing locations & at first very good training. Variety & a good team. Chance to travel to other lovely historic sites . Benefits on old contracts before a charity were good but that has since changed
cons: Long hours. Lack of support. No recognition of staff contribution or in house ideas. Communication extremely poor between departments & other sites

review_title: Management spoilt an otherwise enjoyable work culture
job_title: Consulting Software IT Specialist in Amesbury, England

Working at an amazing historic site.
Engaging with happy and excited visitors from around the world.
Working outside in great weather.
cons:
It seemed that management were instructed from above to spoil you day. 
Working outside in poor weather

review_title: Good opportunities but disorganisation and office politics
